citation.article-title: Falcivibrio grandis gen. nov. sp. nov., and Falcivibrio vaginalis gen. nov. sp. nov., new genus and species to accomodate anaerobic motile curved rods formerly described as Vibrio mulieris, Prevot 1940 Breed et al. 1948.

p.s: Falcivibrio (Fal.ci.vib'ri.o. L. n. falx sickle, crescent; L. v. vibro move rapidly to and fro; M. L. n. vibrio that which vibrates; M. L. masc. n. Falcivibrio the crescent-shaped vibrating organism)
More or less crescent rods, 1 to 5 by 0.4 to 0.6 μm, mostly with pointed ends.
Motile by means of flagella originating polarity at the end or laterally towards the middle of the concave cell side.
Strictly anaerobic, some strains becoming micro-aerotolerant after several passages, and then able to grow in a partially reduced atmosphere containing 5% sheep O2.
Fermentation activities depending on the species.
Slow growth on solid agar media.
Colonies on PYGS or Columbia agar plates with 5% sheep blood or human blood after 3 days of anaerobic incubation at 37°C are white to gray, and pinpoint to 1 mm in diameter.
After 5 days the colonies are larger, 1-2.5 mm in diameter and gray-white or slightly yellowish.
Generally non-hemolytic, but some of the saccharolytic strains show slight greening or weak β-hemolysis in areas of dense growth.
Growth is stimulated by serum or whole blood and by fumarate; fumarate is reduced to succinate and might be oxidized in complex media to malate.
Nitrates may or may not be reduced, depending on the species.
The G + C content of the DNA is 50-54 mol%.
